title: Gas can make us a cleaner energy superpower
text:
According to the green movement, Australia is an environmental vandal for exporting natural gas. If we and other countries stopped profiteering by exporting liquefied natural gas (LNG) to the developing world, the argument goes, we would all shift rapidly to renewables and the world would have averted a climate catastrophe. If only it were so simple. Australia can be a climate champion by developing and exporting renewables, LNG, liquid hydrogen and an essential emissions-reduction technology – carbon capture and storage (CCS).

The latest energy demand and supply outlook for members of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum examines a business-as-usual case and another in which APEC members achieve the commitments they made in the Paris Climate Agreement to limit global temperature rises to no more than two degrees Celsius. Under the business-as-usual case – the path APEC is currently on – members spectacularly fail to meet their Paris commitments. And remember, those commitments are likely to fall well short of what’s actually needed to limit global temperature rises to less than 2 per cent – itself a terrible scenario for humankind and species protection.

Since APEC members include China and rapidly growing countries of southeast Asia such as Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Malaysia, it is not surprising that APEC’s energy demand is projected to increase sharply between now and 2050. A big contributor to that increase will be the demand for air-conditioned living space as both living standards and temperatures continue to rise.

Try telling the people and the governments of those countries that they will just have to sweat it out because they have a responsibility to save the planet that the developed world has badly damaged. In the business-as-usual case, renewable energy supply increases faster than any other conventional source but is forecast to represent only 13 per cent of total energy supply by 2050.

The APEC analysis shows that the Paris commitments simply cannot be met without two major shifts – accelerating the substitution of gas for coal in electricity generation and the deployment of CCS in most APEC economies from 2030 onwards. Gas-fired power stations emit much less carbon per unit of electricity generated than coal-fired plants. By facilitating the displacement of coal-fired capacity with gas plants, Australia can be a strong contributor to the decarbonisation of electricity generation in the APEC region.

But that won’t be enough. The APEC report describes the application of CCS to fossil fuels (including gas) and biomass power plants not as an optional extra but as “paramount.” Sixteen of the 21 APEC economies have carbon-dioxide storage potential. Australia’s CSIRO continues its leading work on CCS technology and Western Australia’s Gorgon CCS project has begun operating, joining 20 other projects operating or under construction around the world. It is now the largest commercial-scale CCS project in the world, putting Australia in a leadership position upon which it could build.
description: Only more Australian gas and carbon capture technology will allow Asia to hit its Paris targets, writes Craig Emerson.
